2: Here's a possible breakdown of the data from the text above: value boundariees:{ "start": -100, "end": 100 }equation:"percentage of elite norm adopters"order_number: 3frequency:"each iteration"The same pattern holds for the other dependent variable, where we see that only two of the fourteen parameters have significant effects on the outcome of norm adoption. Those two parameters are advocate weight and degrade percent. Advocate weight has a positive coefficient, suggesting that the greater the weight given to advocacy networks, the more likely it is that elites will adopt a norm. Degrade percent has a negative coefficient, suggesting that the lower the chance that elites will degrade the message of the advocates, the more likely it is that elites will adopt a norm. We also note that the size of the population does not appear to have much impact on norm adoption rates for either group of actors.  ConclusionThis paper shows that, when presented with the same stimuli, elite actors will have a higher likelihood of adopting a norm than non-elite actors. This conclusion is contrary to the assumption that there is a difference between elites and non-elites in terms of how likely they are to adopt a new norm. It is also contrary to the notion that elites and non-elites would respond similarly to the same stimuli.
